captions.text: [music]
nonameanca from the Internets asks
How do Koreans flirt,
and what's appropriate for a girl to do and what's inappropriate?
As for what's inappropriate, that's very easy.
BUBBLE BUBBLE BUBBLE POP
BUBBLE BUBBLE POP POP
YOOHOO!
Meow!  Meow!  Meow!
AAAAAAARRRRGGGGHHH
That is inappropriate.  Probably won't help you out
Unless you find a guy like this
AAAAAAARRRRGGGGHHH
Yeah, those were inappropriate, weren't they?
Bad ideas.  I don't think anyone would like that in Korea.
Or...in North America
Maybe in some places in North America
Simon and Martina ville
Virginia...and Virginians.
You're scary.
We don't know a single Virginian
Do you know a Virginian?  I don't know any Virginians!
So what's weird about this question is that
it's not that Koreans don't flirt,
It's just that North American style flirting
is so different than Korean style flirting.
It's difficult to say that it's flirting in the same term.
You don't really have that upfront, cocky, pickup line attitude.
As soon as he buy that wine, I just creep up from behind
And ask you what yo interests are.  WHO YOU BE WITH
Things that make you smile...what numbers to dial?
I love it when you call me Big Oppa!
Throw your hands in the air,
and do your homework at the hagwons.
Ahem.  Yes: there aren't pickup lines like that.
Ok so the first thing that we have to say
is that we didn't actually flirt with any Korean people here
because we're very faithfully married to each other,
so we had to ask our Korean friends
who date Korean people for their input.
And we got their input from both our foreign friends who dated Korean people
and from Korean people dating Korean people.
So say you at the club right,
and you see this real fine honey
and you want to pick her up:
instead of giving her a cheesy pickup line,
you gotta talk about what your social status is.
Whoa Whoa Whoa Whoa what just happened to your accent?
It just faded away gangster
Well I'm gradually civilizing myself.
Ok so for example you might say
OH YER SO BYUUTIFUL
You look so nice!
I'd love to take you out on a date somewhere nice.
#1 Social status important thing: having a car!
So having a car is really important,
because a lot of girls will want to be seen in a car
with a tall, good looking Korean guy,
but, unfortunately, if you're not a tall Korean guy and you have a car,
that might not work anyways.
So what we've been told is that
this is kind of just for the shallow girls that you see at the club
not that only shallow girls go to clubs
but if you're trying to pick up somebody
for not, like, really a decent relationship
then you gotta talk about your car and your looks and your money and stuff
Like your watch and your expensive tie
You see this bling?  No?
I don't have any bling.  I'm married!
But is that flaunting social status really that different from North America?
I personally don't think so.
Two shallow people will meet each other via shallow means.
And be shallow together
and be like YEAH WE'VE GOT MONEY.
Let's go do shallow things and we don't really like each other!
However, what is different, is that Korean people
tend to give out phone numbers pretty easily.
because the process afterwards, the text messaging process
is very different than North Americans.
This is really interesting.  This is what our friends told us.
So, in North America, you have the 3 or 4 day call rule.
Like, you know, you get someone's number
and you don't call them or text them
after like a couple of days you call them
Here, it's inverted:
for the first three days you have to text message as much as possible.
It should be small talk, like, they said things like
"Oh!  It's pretty hot today.  I hope you're doing ok"
Or, like "Oh!  What's up tonight?  Are you hanging out with your friends?"
that kind of, like, small chat.
So if you don't do a lot of text messaging within those three days
It shows that you're not interested
And you don't look like a creepy stalker
because you've been playing the rules of the game accordingly.
Now, stepping away from the club life
say you're not a clubby person
Say you want to ask someone out say,
at like a university or a coffee shop
So, unless you already know the person,
like, they're a friend of yours or something,
or unless you're being set up by somebody
like, on a blind date, it doesn't really happen.
Koreans don't really walk up to strangers
and interact in hopes of forming a better relationship.
It just doesn't seem to happen.
Yeah, it doesn't seem like you can have a one day thing.
Like, you're at a coffee shop and you see this beautiful guy or girl
and you kind of go up and start chatting with them
It just doesn't seem to happen.
It seems like you have to know them
for an extended amount of time first
Ok, so say you've hung out with this person for a long time
And you want to take the relationship to the next level.
That's where the adorable confession comes in.
If you guys read any manga or manhwa
or any drama fans or anything like that
And if you guise have ever been to elementary school as well
Be quiet!  It's adorable
The confession is actually really real in Korea
DO YOU LIKE ME!  YES/NO/MAYBE
It's really cute!  I want to tell you a story from my friend.
So if there's this really cute girl and you like her
and you've talked a lot with her
and you're going on a break between university class
You can get her like a little can of coffee that she might like
and you can like, write a note to her about liking her
and then you can stick it on the coffee can
and leave it at her seat
so that when she comes back she finds this can of coffee
with, like, something on it
That kind of thing is apparently common
with leaving confession notes in lockers and stuff like that.
So there is another subtle way of flirting
which I think exists in North America as well
And that's the concept of, like, taking care of the person
For example, if you're going to class with somebody
and you're getting a coffee to study
you might always offer to pay
or if they look thirsty in class you might always bring them a water
Kind of like that oppa idea,
showing that you're paying attention to them
and that you want to take care of them
So, in other words, you're their Sugar Daddy.
What the?  What if I want sugar free cola?
Well then you're their Aspartame daddy.
OH YEAH!
Causing cancer!  Oooh!  Brain rot!
Oh!  And we forgot to answer the part about girls flirting in Korea
Right.  Right!  They don't flirt
They're flirted upon
But they don't really flirt.
Now, these were only our small window of experiences
via our friends living in Korea
so if you have other experiences of flirting in Korea
we'd love to know about it in the comment section.
Write a fan fiction WHAT WHO SAID THAT?
So that's it for this week's TLDR
if there's a question you want us to answer for next TLDR
leave your question in the Google Moderator page
or you can check the questions already asked
and you can vote them up, or vote them down.
and don't forget to subscribe for more TLDRs
We totally forgot about the most important pickup line.
AYYY GIRL!  CAN I BUY YOU A DRINK!
Korean men all over Korea do this.  It's very common.
Oh yeah.  Especially in aprons.
I lied.
GONG!
Sexy intoxicating music.

comments.author: Danny Arias

comments.text:
WOAH. HOLD ON JUST A SEC. I've moved all over the US, (Oahu born) and 
California is my home. I just moved to Virginia (odd name, I know), and 
it's a so-so place... no one seems to know how to cook here... so there's 
that. Summing up this odd state with a list:
1) NO good restaurants. ZIP. :c
    -So-so bakers
    -So-so tea, coffee, and smoothies 
2) Introverted people that are super shy 
3) Great drivers
4) Buku expensive anything [with the exception of gasoline]
5) Fit young people
   -Mainly UVA campus peeps :D
6) Class driven obsessed (I'm not used to, or like, people asking where I 
live)
7) Religious people into the Illuminati (seriously, the Illuminati churches 
are very popular here? Why?)
8) 4 fantastic seasons!!! :D <3
9) Plenty of available so-so paying jobs
10) Nature is cool, but then the wasps ruin it. **shutters** D:

Nailed it. Most things are either so-so, or shocking. Welcome. c:﻿

comments.author: _Anonymous_Monopoly_Turtle_

comments.text:
So there's this Korean guy I'm interested in at school. There is one MAJOR 
problem, though.

The language barrier is as thick as a thick wall. I don't understand Korean 
very well and the same applies to him but with English.

I don't know what to do. I really want to talk to him but, again, the 
language barrier is huge.

He's in my gym class and so I asked his name and said hi to him some times. 
I usually just try to sit next to him while we're on the bleachers or stand 
next to him while we wait for the bell to ring in the last 2 minutes or so 
of class. I'm really shy, too. I have tried making eye contact, but it's a 
bit difficult.

What should I do? :/﻿

comments.text:
As an American, I've never experienced anyone waiting 3-5 days to text or 
call me. Guys who are interested in me will usually text me right away and 
keep conversation like how you described the Koreans doing. If I don't hear 
from them for a few days I assume they were never interested. If they do 
take a few days to contact me, they usually apologize and give some excuse 
that they were busy or something.﻿

comments.author: HannahBelle Sykes

comments.text:
That's not exactly true about girls not flirting or something like that. I 
was stationed in Seoul when I was in the military and one day I was walking 
with a Korean friend I met by the way of her sister. And as we walked by 
some junior high or high school I could hear some of the girls saying 
something out the windows they were looking at us through and sticking 
their heads out. I didn't know much Korean and my friend told me after we 
passed by the bus stop she said they were saying I was cute, look so nice, 
such things.  So I do not know if that would pass as really flirting or 
not. ^_= :p﻿
comments.author: CrstnJdiKnight

comments.text:
I'm still a little confused.  I have a few Korean male friends, and based 
on this some of them are flirting??  Friend A made it a point to help me 
pick a place to stay in Korea when I visit, but we don't talk all that 
often because he is busy with school.  Friend B will text me fairly often 
but he too is busy with school.  Friend B will text at random hours to say 
good night and sweet dreams and sends selfies every now and again.  Friend 
B is quite entertaining when we Skype, he makes it a point to slowly blink 
and do a close up of his eyes showing his natural double eye lid.  Friend B 
is trying to talk me into changing when I visit Korea and flying to the 
airport nearest him so he can take me to a water park and he always says he 
really wants to hang out with me and show me around Korea. Friend C always 
drives when we go somewhere and always pays.  Friend C texts me almost 
every day and said when I visit since his work schedule is flexible he will 
escort me around Seoul one day.  Friend C also looked at where I was going 
to stay and wanted to know the exact location, how far it was from the 
subway etc. and was very specific with where I should stay.  Are they just 
being nice or flirting?  I'm not very sure after at this point.  Friend B 
may be flirting a little, but I don't think so.  Friend C just seems to be 
a nice guy, not flighting right??﻿
comments.author: Harley Quinn

comments.text:

Only one entry so far, but there are many more to come!
comments.author: Harlene Quinzell

comments.text:
+Harley Quinn /.\ yes do a vlog i'd like to see how seoul looks like ^-^ 
once i get older i also would like to visit korea and gurl i wish i could

comments.author: Lovely FancyWorld

comments.text:
Let's make it even more confusing! Friend B started sending me tons of 
pictures and short videos of he and his nephew (super cute kid, love him!) 
He also said if he couldn't get time off work when I visit he would quit 
his job, possibly, since its close to time for him to go back to school. He 
then said if he was able to go to the University near me he wants to be my 
roommate! I started thinking "omo, this is serious!" After that I 
approached him more cautiously. Friend C always questioned who I was going 
to see while in Korea. He would ask "your friend, he or she?" That threw me 
off and I wasn't sure how to answer. Friend B got gifts on Valentines Day 
so I thought everything was fine, were just friends. Then he told me he was 
going to stay with me a few days after I got to Seoul then I was going to 
stay with his family when I visit his home town. He'd already spoken to 
them and it was settled. I was back to being confused. He asked for a pair 
of sneakers, saying he would give me the money when I get there. I said 
sure, then he picked a pair for me. They were the low top version of the 
ones he wanted. Looked like couple shoes to me so I made it a point to 
mention the matching shoes, staying with his family and all that. I thanked 
him for going to such great lengths. He said it was because he was Korean 
and he wants to make sure I have a good time when I visit Korea. So he's 
just being nice? Aigoo! I don't know! Friend C took me to a very expensive 
dinner his last night here and made sure I had his number in Korea and his 
KT ID so we stay in touch. He still pressed me about my friend asking he or 
she LOL add to that friend C and I went to dinner every week. He would help 
me with my Korean after we ate, which is the only part of the evening that 
kept it from feeling like a date. I asked why he always drove, his answer 
was "in Korea the man always drives!" .....I thought that was only when 
dating, or is that for everything? I'm so confused! My trip is fast 
approaching so I'll find out then. Maybe I should Blog and Vlog my trip and 
experiences??

comments.author: sleepy devil

comments.text:
Ok I know this video is several years old, but I'm going to answer the 
question.  When I was a teen I lived in Atlanta, Georgia and there was a 
girl from South Korea who decided that she and I were soul mates and she 
loved me and was all obsessive and creepy with out even asking me if I 
wanted to date her.  It was awkward because I had a girl friend already, 
she was not happy about this creepy girl.  It was kinda crazy.  I remember 
one day I was home sick and not feeling social, and the creepy girl decided 
that she was going to visit me.....with out making sure it was ok first.  I 
was not happy to see her.  She didn't seem to understand subtlety either. 
 I tried to "break up" with her a few times, finally I had to say "Look I'm 
dating so-and-so and not you.  I never wanted to date you. I'm sorry but 
don't call me or text me again."  It sucked﻿

comments.text:
i've been in korea for about 5 months now, and i've noticed this thing 
about korean males, is that they dont really flirt, it's like they say 
really nice things to you, and offer to go places and stuff like that and 
just try to talk to you as much as they can. it's very cute.and you know 
they like you because its just kind of obvious. im in the army so we work 
with katusas which are korean soldiers working with american soldiers, and 
ive noticed that its not okay to hang out with or talk to an american girl 
however it is really cool for a american guy to talk to alot of korean 
girls and its easier for them. its a really strange thing which has never 
made any sense to me.﻿

comments.author: Vik G

comments.text:
I'm not sure you understand even the point of this video. This is the idea 
of "Picking up chicks" idea, where you go out to a club or bar for the 
specific purpose of having a short-term relationship for some genuinely 
shallow reasons. Pretty much every where in the world requires to meet a 
certain requirement before being able to show up to a club and start asking 
to take girls home. Most of it is down to attraction, but in Korea it's not 
uncommon by any means to meet someone who is really good looking, so you 
see two good looking people but you don't actually care about both of them 
personally then the idea is that said person can find interest in the one 
that will show them a better time. Whether it be something simple as 
driving them home over getting a cab or something a little more personal 
and that you share similar fashion sense.
